Award.AwardTitle: Deciphering light induced double bond isomerization in proteins
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is supporting the research of Professor Olivucci of the Bowling Green State University. With the help of Dr. Xu, a microbiologist working in the same institution, Dr. Olivucci intends to study the mechanism of double-bond photoisomerization in protein mutants by combining quantum chemistry and genetic techniques. The research focuses on a photochromic sensory rhodopsin from the cyanobacterium Anabaena (ASR) as a reference lab model. The investigators will construct, starting from known crystallographic data, computer models of the ASR wild-type and of a series of its mutants and study the changes in their photoisomerization dynamics via excited state trajectory computations. A sub-set of these mutants will be constructed in the laboratory for validation purposes. The investigators seek to analyze the information derived by the study of multiple series of mutants, and in so doing gain an understanding of how specific amino acid replacements can tune/control the photoisomerization.

The Broader Impact of this project emerges from the possibility to use computation in predicting and ultimately designing the photochemical properties of chromophore-containing proteins. The project stimulates collaboration across distant disciplines: computational quantum chemistry and molecular biology. Accordingly, the graduate students will receive a multidisciplinary training. The results will be disseminated not only through the conventional media but also through the on-line publication of a Protein Model Database. The results will also help to improve the quality of undergraduate/graduate courses at BGSU and thought via long-distance learning technologies. Professor Olivucci supports the undergraduate BGSU program Building Ohio's Sustainable Energy Future by teaching how to use computers and computational chemistry tools to characterize the absorption spectra of organic compounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the first three years of the project and, consistently, during the final fourth year, the PI objective has been the design and implementation of a new computational technology for carrying out systematic studies of the dynamics and mechanism of light-induced double-bond isomerization in proteins. The project objective have been reached through three substantially sequential phases: (a) the design, implementation and benchmarking of an automatic computational protocol for the construction of QM/MM rhodopsin and rhodopsin mutant models, (b) the application of such protocol to the generation and investigation of ASR mutants so wide to make their experimental screening impossible and (c) the extraction from the obtained pull of data of "rules" useful for the engineering rhodopsins with desired spectral and reactivity properties. The results of the research have been documented, overal, in 22 published papers (all acknowledge the NSF funding) including two reports in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA addressing the problem of consistently simulating non-homologous retinal proteins such as vertebrate, invertebrate and microbial pigments, and one paper in Nature’s Scientific Reports focused on the ecology of freshwater fish visual rhodopsins. These publications include a tutorial published in Chemical Society Review which discusses how to use computational photochemistry to design biomimetic materials. The tutorial was selected to be one of the top referee-recommended article of the month (http://blogs.rsc.org/cs/2014/07/22/hot-chem-soc-rev-articles-for-july/).

The research has opened new perspectives in the field of modeling proteins which are responsive to light including the vertebrate visual pigments (i.e. the retina pigment). The methods developed and implemented in a software tool in the present research can be used to study at the atomic-level and in comparative way, rhodpsins with different functions (i.e. pigments that percieved different colors). It can also be used to investigate how mutations change such function. This last use of our tool may ultimately give access to the possibility of performing an in silico evolution of proteins and, therefore, to engineer them to get novel rhodopsin-based genetically ancodable sensors and actuators useful, for instance, in biophysical studies, diganostics and microscopy. Bisides applicative studies, the developed tool will be used for mechanistic study. In general, it will be possible to emply the constructed model to investigate how the protein residues control the color and the function of their embedded chromophores. This information is vital to develop a coherent understanding or biophysical theory of protein chromophore functional interations.

The computational chemistry taught at the undergraduate and even graduate levels do not usually incorporate fascinating topics such as the modeling of visual pigments: proteins that allow us to see. On the other hand, undergraduates are told that computer simulations can help to achieve an atomic-level understanding of the function or biological macromolecules including visual pigments. The automatically generated models achieved through our four-year project allow graduate and undergraduate and, most likely, which only require a basic knowledge of protein structure for being correctly constructed, provide an effective tool to fill such a gap. Hopefully, the developed of such a new teaching strategy will be supported by NSF in the near future.

We strongly believe that the developed software will create unique opportunity for teaching and stimulate the interest for advanced computational chemistry at the undergraduate level (starting at the college junior level). In fact, the fact the automatic production of models of biological photoreceptors performed by such software, will make possible its use after a minimal training or demonstration. Undegraduates will be able to model full proteins and their structural, spectroscopic and reactivity properties. Teachers will the be able to link basic concepts in physics and chemistry to simulations of attractive molecular systems that the tudents cna exlore visually. The students will also be free to explore the system behaviour upon a change in molecular elements and therefore learn the connection between structure and properties directly on a macromolecular system. 

In order to facilitate the activity above we have also provided, as an otcome of the research, a database of ARM models (e.g. all models presented in Melaccio F. et al.  (2016) Towards Automatic Rhodopsin Modeling as a Tool for High-throughput Computational Photobiology Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation doi:10.1021/acs.jctc.6b00367) of rhodopsins. A database has already been started and will be made available on-line to the scientific community. The scientific community will also be provided with an on-line server where to perform the simulation with the developed software.
